Censorship serves to shield specific age groups from disturbing images, sounds, or ideas. However, in the context of libraries, implementing censorship would necessitate the removal of all books from the shelves. Consequently, if library books are removed, books in bookstores would also have to be discarded.  Books are an indispensable part of life. They encapsulate profound ideas and thoughts, expressed through the art of words. Those who advocate for the censorship of library books are misguided. Their intention to safeguard their children and themselves is understandable, yet this decision inflicts harm on others. Authors are aggrieved as their creative works are being censored. Readers who enjoy the books targeted for censorship will no longer have access to them.  Ultimately, it is an individual's prerogative to avoid books they find offensive. They should not go to extreme lengths to censor them, as this may lead to a situation where people start to believe that any book could be subject to censorship. If this occurs, library shelves will be emptied. The government may take notice and ban these books or, in a worst - case scenario, remove all books permanently, as was the case in [CAPS1] [NUM1].  In conclusion, books are a positive force. They inspire us and help us navigate life with the insights they offer. It is up to each individual to avoid books that distress them, rather than being influenced by the opinions of others.

Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, magazines, etc., should be removed from library shelves if they are deemed offensive? Absolutely not. The reason is that what may be offensive to me might not be offensive to others. I am not suggesting that such materials are offensive to me; in fact, I personally relish reading comic books featuring superheroes, which greatly excites me.  To return to the main point, if individuals find a book offensive, they simply need not pick it up. If I were aware that a book would be offensive to me, I would never choose to read it. I anticipate the question: 'But what if they didn't know it would be offensive?' This is a valid question. In such a case, one should simply put the book back and refrain from complaining, as the author likely had no intention of causing offense. They were merely expressing their ideas in a book.  It is not the author's fault. They were probably writing a book they considered to be of high quality. When the book is published and a reader takes offense, it is unfair to blame the author. Therefore, we should not remove books from library shelves simply because some individuals are overly sensitive and take offense. Doing so would ruin the experience for other readers who may find the book excellent or amazing.  Now that we have addressed this issue, let us move forward and continue with our lives. Thank you for this discussion. Until next time.

Society perpetually grapples with the delineation between what is proper and what is not. Daily, we are privy to such matters, even when not actively seeking them. It represents the age - old contention between two factions endeavoring to discredit one another, determining what is acceptable and what is not. We ought to exert every effort to preclude inappropriate books from our shelves and the hands of the youth. People are malleable and can be swayed to undertake almost any action. There are innumerable such instances, making it arduous to single out just one. Intriguingly, individuals can be indirectly influenced. Whether through television, music, or books, humans can be shaped according to what they are conditioned to believe. The influences one encounters can be either beneficial or detrimental. As an individual with the best interests of society at heart, I am cognizant that movies featuring criminal acts or explicit imagery do not contribute to the betterment of citizens. The same holds true for books. Books conveying politically incorrect messages are no more commendable than movies with similar content. I am by no means opposed to reading; in fact, I am quite the contrary. Reading is generally advantageous for mental and social well - being as it enables us to explore latent aspects of ourselves that often go untapped in our fast - paced world. However, if one is constantly exposed to books contrary to human nature, they should be removed for the common good. If an individual cannot find an appropriate book to read, they should introspect. There are millions of books that are not only engaging and stimulating but also capable of exerting a positive influence. As members of the @ORGANIZATION1, we already face sufficient challenges, particularly financial ones. We need not exacerbate the situation by allowing the public access to obscene books that typically breed rebellion against society. If something incites the populace to be more unruly, it should be promptly censored or eradicated from society. Believe it or not, it is possible to have fun while imparting a positive message.

Dear Newspaper, In libraries, I opine that it is unnecessary to remove materials that some may find offensive. After all, if something offends an individual, they have the prerogative to avoid it. Each person is autonomous and can make independent decisions. If so - called offensive material is not deemed offensive by someone, then why should that person be penalized by those who overreact? Just because one person dislikes something does not imply that others will share the same sentiment. If someone deems a book offensive, they should refrain from reading it; if a magazine is offensive, the same principle applies. It is that straightforward. People are discerning enough to distinguish between what is beneficial and what is detrimental to them. There is no valid reason why individuals cannot select what they desire and from where they wish to obtain it. Based on my personal observations, I have witnessed numerous instances where someone found another's music offensive but chose to remain silent and ignore it. The world needs more individuals of this ilkâ€”those who stand firm in their beliefs and refrain from passing judgment on others' beliefs. It appears that the world is becoming inundated with people overly preoccupied with others' actions. While this is not inherently negative, everyone will encounter something offensive at some point. It is a personal choice whether to let it vex them for the rest of their lives. One should feel free to listen to any music, read any books or magazines they desire. If others find these offensive, so be it. Each person is unique, and this will never change. One should pursue activities that bring happiness and nothing else.

Why engage in censorship? There will always be individuals eager to read books or magazines that others advocate censoring. If this vicious cycle persists, we will eventually be left with no reading material. There are numerous things that some people dislike, but this does not grant them the right to remove such items from the shelves. Removing a book simply because they consider it inappropriate leaves someone without reading options. If books and magazines start being removed from the shelves, our means of researching and learning certain subjects will be diminished. Even if books or magazines contain graphic pictures or explicit writing, it does not render them inappropriate. They should be clearly labeled to indicate the presence of such content. If one sees the label and wishes to avoid it, they can. We need to categorize books according to age groups. This way, parents can be assured that their children can only access age - appropriate books. With parental consent, children can read books intended for older individuals. Although I am not an avid reader, I occasionally pick up books to learn about engines. I believe that people should not have the power to restrict access to materials and remove them from the shelves. Everyone has the right to read a book, watch a movie, etc. However, children are an exception as they do not need to be exposed to certain content at a young age. Parents can thus determine what their children read. As an adult, one should have the freedom to read, listen, or watch whatever they choose.

There are numerous elements in this world that children should not be exposed to as they can corrupt the minds of children and individuals of all ages. The content people encounter today can be detrimental and should not be witnessed by anyone, regardless of their age. Such materials should be eliminated to safeguard the purity of our minds and those of future generations. I believe that no one, regardless of age, should be exposed to such negative content. If children should be shielded from certain things, there is no reason why adults, who were once children, should be exposed to them. However, when such content is present in libraries, the question arises: who should be responsible for determining what is right and wrong? Given the vast global population and the diverse range of opinions, it is impossible for a single person to review all materials and make such distinctions. Hence, it falls upon the heads of families to address this issue and make decisions regarding their children's exposure to such content.

I contend that certain materials should not be readily accessible on the shelves but should not be removed from the library. There should be a dedicated room housing all materials that may potentially offend someone, including books, music, movies, magazines, etc. Some materials in a public library are justifiable, but adult - oriented items should be placed on higher shelves to prevent young children from reaching them. The library should have a separate room for children and teenagers, stocked with age - appropriate books, magazines, music, and movies. Children should not be permitted in areas of the library that are violent or sexual in nature. Additionally, the library should have a locked room for adult movies and books, as well as a room for children. If the library lacks the funds for these rooms, it can at least place all adult materials on high shelves. I believe that while some materials should not be prominently displayed, they should not be removed from the library. Someone may need a particular book for school or work research. Removing materials can also erase a part of history from the library. After all, there is a reason these materials were created and are present in the library. Parents can also assist the library by closely monitoring their children, watching what they pick from the shelves. They can even enlist the help of a friend or neighbor to watch the children while they visit the library, ensuring that the kids do not encounter inappropriate content. I firmly believe that the suggestions I have presented are the ideal approach for a public library. Adult materials should be placed out of reach. If parents are dissatisfied, they can choose to leave their children at home or patronize a different library.

In a single library, an extensive array of books, music, films, and magazines is available. Globally, individuals possess diverse interests in various subjects. Certain individuals may take umbrage at specific books, songs, movies, magazines, and so forth. Conversely, another person might not perceive them as offensive at all. For instance, a religious book that portrays @CAPS1 as a single individual when some people hold different beliefs. Such a book should not be removed, as there are also books that align with one's own beliefs. The assortment of subjects in a library, including songs, magazines, and all other items, is vast. A book, movie, or item should never be removed simply because one person takes offense to it. As Katherine Paterson's quote posits, if someone decides to remove a book from the shelf, anyone could do the same. This would ultimately leave people with a lack of variety in books, which would pose a significant problem. People would be unable to read as extensively as they desire because they would not have the option to choose from a multitude of materials. Libraries offer information for teachers, students, researchers, writers, and readers who engage in reading as a hobby. If this resource were taken away from people, they would become less informed about numerous aspects of the world. In @CAPS2, freedom is of utmost importance and is expected, including freedom of speech and the freedom to hold one's own opinions and interests. Therefore, if items were being removed from a public place that provides such freedoms, @CAPS2 would not permit this to occur. People have the right to like whatever they wish. If someone takes offense to an item in the library, they should simply disregard it and refrain from insisting on its removal.

It truly does not matter to me, as we all have the right to our own preferences and aversions. Someone might not believe that movies containing blood should be permitted, while others might think that movies with adult content should not be allowed. If you dislike something and someone else likes it, why should you get your way and not theirs? So, if we remove one movie, book, magazine, type of song, or piece of music from the market, why not remove them all? Then, there would be no debate about what is suitable to watch and what is not. If you dislike something or have young children and do not want them to watch, read, or view something, then simply do not purchase it. If you do buy it, ensure that it is out of their reach. In conclusion, respecting individual preferences and taking appropriate precautions regarding content access is the most reasonable approach in this matter.

Books, music, films, magazines, and the like should be removed from the shelves because young children should not be exposed to their content through viewing, seeing, or hearing. Violence is detrimental for young children to witness, as it may lead them to aspire to engage in fighting as they grow older. In my opinion, movies should be removed from circulation as they are a significant factor in children learning to fight. Children observe older kids fighting and are inclined to imitate such behavior. Movies exert a negative influence on young children when it comes to fighting and killing, and they can also prompt children to become bullies. When a child becomes a bully, they may not fully comprehend the consequences of their actions. Another concerning example is the portrayal of drugs and alcohol. Teenagers and other children are frequently subjected to peer pressure. When faced with peer pressure, it is challenging for them to say no. The type of music people listen to can also have a negative impact on children. The music that children listen to often contains references to killing, drugs, and alcohol. When children become involved in drugs and alcohol, it can ruin their entire lives. For example, screamo music, to me, sounds as if someone is being killed or beaten. Magazines are also inappropriate for teenagers and children to peruse. Magazines often feature inappropriate images, and when teenagers see these images, they may aspire to emulate the people depicted in them. Due to the prevalence of violence in books, movies, music, and magazines, they should be removed from the shelves. There are numerous fights and instances where teenagers subject other children to peer pressure. Therefore, I earnestly urge you to remove these materials from the shelves to safeguard the well - being of young people.

However, these materials may seem racial to those who have endured these difficult periods, and the attempts to explain the pain they experienced may appear as a mockery to them, even though this is not the intended meaning at all. In conclusion, while we should respect the right to access historical and educational materials, we must also take steps to eliminate content that is truly intended to mock and harm different races.

Should offensive books be removed from library shelves? Some books in libraries may be offensive to certain individuals, but should they be removed? Personally, I do not believe that these books should be removed. Some people may think that the books need to be removed, while others do not. What is your stance on this challenging question? Firstly, as I previously mentioned, I do not think it is justifiable to remove these books. Some people may not agree with my opinion. These books should not be removed simply because they offend others. If someone finds a book offensive, they should simply ignore it rather than demanding its removal from the shelf. There may be others who wish to read that book, and removing it would be unfair to them. The book that is offensive to someone is not necessarily targeted at them, and the author's opinion should not be the sole determinant. Secondly, everyone's opinion varies. Some people advocate for the removal of the books, while others do not. So, whose opinion should prevail in this debate? I believe that the books should remain on the shelves. One person may find a book offensive, while another may not. Some people may not even read the offensive book. Regardless of whether the book is read or not, it should not be removed from the shelf, as this would be unfair to those who actually want to read it. Lastly, everyone has different preferences when it comes to book themes. If you do not like the theme of a book, then why are you reading it? If you dislike a book or find it offensive, simply choose another one. Do not prevent others from reading a book if they enjoy its theme. You would not appreciate it if the same were done to you, and neither would anyone else. Just select a book with a theme that appeals to you. In conclusion, I firmly believe that it is unfair to remove books from the shelf simply because some people find them offensive. People have diverse tastes and opinions, and a book that is offensive to one person may be valuable to another. Therefore, we should respect the right of all individuals to access the books they desire.

Censorship in Libraries I believe that censorship in a library can be justifiable as some individuals may feel that children should not be exposed to certain content. In this way, both the concerns of those worried about inappropriate content and the rights of those who wish to access a wide range of materials can be respected. Libraries serve as repositories where anyone can discover books on any topic of their choosing. This right should remain firmly in the hands of readers, rather than being dictated by libraries. Every individual has the freedom to explore whatever subjects they find appealing, and library staff should not exert influence over which books people read.  Censorship of books is entirely unnecessary. If someone wishes to read about a particular topic, they have the legitimate right to do so. Encountering an offensive book is a matter of personal choice; no one forces a reader to pick it up. Once a reader realizes that a book is offensive, they can decide not to continue reading. However, just because one reader finds a book offensive does not mean that another person will share the same view, and that other person has the right to read the book if they so choose.  Deeming a book offensive is merely an opinion, lacking factual basis. So, who has the authority to determine whether a book is offensive? Just because a library administrator believes a book to be offensive or inappropriate, it does not justify removing it from the shelves. There is no single individual who can definitively pronounce a book as offensive.  Other media such as music, movies, and magazines should also remain uncensored, although some are already subject to certain restrictions. Movies, for example, are rated, which allows viewers to select the level of content they are comfortable with. Viewers should not expect to borrow a rated '@CAPS1' movie and encounter no material with profanity, violence, or other 'offensive' elements. By choosing a higher - rated movie, viewers are making their own decisions about what they watch, and librarians should not take it upon themselves to remove these films. It is not their responsibility.  Music is also rated, and when necessary, it comes with a parental warning label indicating explicit content. Similar to movies and books, everyone has the right to listen to the music of their choice and should not be forced to search elsewhere because a librarian deems it inappropriate.  Magazines may not be rated, but that does not give libraries the right to make executive decisions about rating them and discarding those considered 'offensive'. As previously mentioned, it is the reader's prerogative to access material, not the librarian's.  Whether it is books, music, movies, or magazines, consumers have the right to read, listen to, or view whatever they desire without the interference of librarians. Each person has the autonomy to decide what media they consume, and no one else has the right to dictate otherwise. In conclusion, the freedom of choice in accessing library materials should be protected and respected.

Should certain offensive material be removed from library shelves? Many individuals find materials in libraries, such as books, movies, music, and magazines, offensive. However, does this imply that they should be removed? I, along with numerous others, believe that libraries should not censor offensive materials. Censoring libraries would shirk parental responsibilities, undermine our profitable media, and be unconstitutional.  Parents are accountable for their children, not only in terms of providing sustenance and shelter but also when their children are exposed to inappropriate or offensive material. If one does not want their child to be offended or exposed to vulgar shows, texts, and music, they should prevent them from accessing such content. For example, if a child is listening to a sexually explicit song on their iPod, parents should confiscate it. Owning such a device is a privilege, not a right, and parents have the authority to revoke privileges.  In addition to neglecting parental responsibilities, it would be a substantial economic blow to the media. Most media is popular precisely because of the inappropriate content in shows, books, and music. If all such content is censored, fewer movie tickets will be purchased, fewer books will be sold, and less music will be listened to. In a period of recession, like the one we are emerging from, it is more advantageous to generate as much income as possible rather than squandering existing profit - making opportunities.  Both of these points are valid, but most importantly, censoring libraries would be unconstitutional. The preamble of our laws grants us the rights to freedom of speech and the press. These offensive materials fall within the scope of these rights. I understand that amendments can be added to specify appropriate forms of speech and the press, but how would officials monitor this? Not to mention the vast amount of jail space that would be required for those smuggling inappropriate materials to buyers.  In brief, censoring libraries is a poor idea in terms of parental responsibilities, media economics, and our constitutional rights. The negative consequences of such an action far outweigh the potential benefits. Evidently, censorship is not the solution to offensive material.

Allow your mind to drift to a realm of peace and tranquility. You find yourself in a world of boundless possibilities. Libraries are among the primary resources for research, reading, and the acquisition of information and knowledge. Most people have used, currently use, or will use a library in their lifetime. This indicates that it is not beneficial for a child to be exposed to such offensive content. Censorship, in the form of moving the books to a new location, is the optimal choice.  Another reason I believe the books should not be removed completely but rather relocated within the library is that everyone has the right to express their opinions and feelings on a subject. Others also have the right to express their views on someone else's thoughts. Just because one finds something offensive does not justify taking it away from others. I believe that if a person desires to access such content, they have the right and the choice to do so. However, those who do not wish to encounter it should also have the option to avoid it. This is why the books should not be left in the open for all to see but rather placed in a secluded section.  In conclusion, the most effective solution for dealing with offensive material in libraries is not to remove it entirely but to section it off from the rest and provide access only to those who actively seek it. Everyone should have the choice and the right to view or avoid certain material they may find offensive. By doing so, the library will become a more suitable environment for all its users.

Some movies are highly offensive and should be removed from the shelves. Another issue pertains to magazines. There is a wide variety of magazines with diverse content, and their availability needs to be regulated. I firmly believe that any offensive material should be removed from the shelves.  Some individuals are overly sensitive, and the world is filled with offensive elements. People should consider the feelings of others. Otherwise, misunderstandings may occur, leading to unpleasant situations.

I dissent from the notion that certain offensive materials, such as books, movies, or magazines, should be removed from library shelves. There are three compelling reasons for my stance on this matter. Firstly, inappropriate materials, including books and music, should not be placed in sections where children typically search for books. Secondly, when a child attempts to check out an inappropriate book, they should be required to present identification to verify their age. Thirdly, I believe that such materials should remain on the shelves because adults have legitimate reasons for accessing books, movies, music, and other forms of media.  There should be no inappropriate content in libraries that children can easily access. Children should only have access to appropriate materials, alleviating parents' concerns about what their children hear, see, or read. Some libraries allow children to borrow magazines or books without proper supervision, which is where the problem begins.  All libraries should implement a system to identify each child when they check out a book, magazine, or music. Similar to movie ratings, which inform parents about the content of a film, parents should closely monitor what their children read and watch.  I believe that inappropriate materials should remain on the shelves but should be confined to the adult section of the library. Children should not be permitted to enter the adult section. In some cases, these materials can be valuable to adults. There is certain material that adults may need to enhance their lives.  In conclusion, children should not have access to inappropriate materials in libraries. Libraries should implement measures to ensure that only appropriate materials are accessible to children, while adults should have access to such materials on the library shelves.

If you were an author, would you consider it just for someone to remove your creation from the shelves due to its potential to offend? In my view, there are indeed certain references, including movies, books, music, magazines, and more, that may be deemed inappropriate. However, I contend that no one should have the right to remove them from the shelves solely because they find them offensive.  If everyone had the authority to remove something from a shelf based on personal offense, there would be little left. In my opinion, virtually anything has the potential to offend someone. For instance, I once read a book that stereotyped cheerleaders, a common occurrence. The portrayal of cheerleaders in the book was distasteful. As someone who has been actively involved in cheerleading throughout my life, I was mildly offended because I did not fit the description in the book. Although I did not enjoy the book, I recognized that it was my choice to read it. I did not feel compelled to return to the bookstore and demand its removal from the market simply because I, as an individual, did not like it.  My philosophy is to disregard things that I do not like or refrain from purchasing items that offend me. I am aware that the intended audience of some books or movies may not be the only ones who encounter them. For example, a child may come across a movie containing inappropriate language or scenes. In such cases, I believe one should simply move on and focus on materials that are suitable for them. Parents should also take responsibility for censoring what their children see, hear, and read.  Moreover, I do not believe it is fair to remove someone's creative work, whether it is music, a book, a magazine, or a movie, from display or the shelves. These authors and creators have invested significant time and effort into their work. Just because a particular piece of work may not appeal to one person does not mean it will not resonate with others.  In conclusion, I do not think it is justifiable to remove items from the market because they do not please a few individuals. I am confident that there are people out there who will appreciate and enjoy these works. It would be unfair to the artists who have dedicated their time and effort to creating them. Everything on the market has the potential to offend someone in some way, but that is a reality of the world. People should learn to accept this and either ignore the offensive content or find a way to deal with it.

In the absence of books, our knowledge would be severely limited. It is akin to suggesting that a body can function without a heart. They facilitate a deeper understanding of various concepts that others may not be aware of or comprehend. The same principle applies to music, movies, and magazines.  I fully understand the concerns of parents, guardians, and caregivers. However, they must recognize that what they perceive as detrimental to society may actually be beneficial to others. Different individuals hold diverse perspectives. Books are an alternative means of learning, and not all are harmful to the younger generation or anyone else. They also enhance our understanding of numerous aspects of life.  It is not solely books that pose a concern; there are also certain movies, music, and magazines. However, many of these indicate the appropriate age range for consumption. Movies are rated, such as '@NUM1, @CAPS1', providing guidance to viewers. For music, one can examine the song lyrics on the back of the album to determine if there is any inappropriate content. Magazines come in a wide variety of topics suitable for all ages, allowing individuals to select those appropriate for themselves or their children.  Not everything is negative; it is a matter of personal judgment regarding what is suitable for one's child or others. One cannot hold others accountable for their opinions on what needs to be heard or said. We must think outside the box and recognize that there are people who genuinely need to access certain information, experiences, or resources to improve themselves as individuals. People are often quick to judge without attempting to understand that everyone requires support and that just because one's life may seem on the right track does not mean others cannot change for the better.  If these forms of media were removed from our lives, the world would be a poorer place. We already struggle to fully comprehend some of the content in books, music, movies, and magazines. Imagine a world without them; it would be a dismal sight. We should embrace the resources we have and utilize them to the best of our ability, as they all serve a purpose.

In my opinion, materials that are offensive to some individuals should not be removed from the shelves. If someone finds certain materials offensive, they should simply ignore them. For example, I once watched a television show that made racial stereotypes about @CAPS1 - @CAPS2. As a cheerleader, I was slightly offended, but I recognized that it was just a show aiming to increase ratings. I continued to watch the show the next night.  If historical figures had heeded every negative comment made about them, our black culture and history would not be as rich and vibrant as it is today. I might not even have the opportunity to take this test. Therefore, we should not take everything too seriously, as everyone has a unique sense of humor.  If we were to remove all offensive content from the media, many of our favorite actors and singers would not have achieved the fame and success they enjoy today. Award shows and music genres would lose their charm. Some artists use offensive language in their songs, but they release these songs because words are just words.  In conclusion, anyone and anything can be either offensive or offended. We should not take everything to heart, as it may just be a joke or the attention - seeking behavior of an ignorant person. My mother always said, "Sticks and stones may break your bones, but words only make you." We should not take the media too seriously, as it is often just for entertainment. Certainly not. I do not believe that such an event should transpire as it would be utterly foolish, and I am confident that a substantial number of individuals would oppose it. Removing literature from the shelves solely based on personal opinion should not be permitted. Individuals hold diverse perspectives on what is appropriate and inappropriate. Does censorship genuinely aid or impede our libraries? Not only is it detrimental to a society, but it's also clearly unconstitutional when examined in light of the @CAPS1 of the @ORGANIZATION1. Throughout my existence, I have encountered numerous books that appear objectionable to me. Nevertheless, they ought not to be censored merely because they seem offensive. I am of the opinion that books deemed offensive should not be censored. Classifying something as offensive is a subjective opinion. Unless every person in the entire world regarded a book as offensive, it should remain accessible to the public. Another reason why we should refrain from censoring books found to be offensive is that in our @LOCATION1, we are granted the right to express ourselves freely. If we were to censor books deemed offensive, we would be infringing upon this right. This would be unfair to the authors of the books and to those who appreciate them. The subsequent reason why we should not censor books found offensive is that if we were to censor every book we found objectionable, we would have no books to read at all. For instance, assume that several people adored the @ORGANIZATION1 @ORGANIZATION1 series, but another person who read it later found it offensive and had it censored. The people who loved the @ORGANIZATION1 series would then seek out the books the other person likes and censor them. If this pattern persisted, we would have no books to read. Unless having books that seem offensive is more detrimental than having the events we fear recur, then books found offensive should not be censored. I firmly believe that books found to be offensive should not be censored because without them, we would be violating the right to free expression, and we would be allowing the terrible events of the past to be forgotten. Without books considered offensive, we would have no books to read at all.

They will ultimately perceive it. I am convinced that there is no valid reason to censor a library. I contend that everyone holds diverse views on various matters, and thus, I do not believe that books should be censored because doing so would violate the First Amendment, which guarantees everyone the freedom of religion and speech. I am aware that some people believe that everyone should view things the same way and that everyone should agree and get along, but this is not realistic. No matter how much one desires people to agree and get along, it will never be fully achievable. I believe people need to mind their own business and allow others to read, listen to, and watch whatever they choose, without causing offense. I understand that some people believe they know everything because they have their own ways of thinking. Arguing with such people is futile, as one will never win the argument or make them understand one's perspective. They simply believe that their way is the only correct way. This is my stance on people becoming angry when there is a book or movie on the shelf that they do not agree with. I believe that everyone should attempt to understand what others are saying and listen to them, rather than ignoring them. I hold this view, and I am not someone who is inflexible in my opinions.

I am of the opinion that if something is deemed offensive to one person, it does not necessarily mean it will be offensive to another.
