Moving offensive books to a higher shelf can keep them out of children's sight and reach, preventing them from accessing and reading these books. Designating a particular area for these books in the library creates a 'barrier'. You can instruct your child to avoid this area and monitor them to ensure they comply. Additionally, you'll know where these books are located and can prevent your child from approaching. Imposing an age limit on borrowing offensive books restricts children from checking them out. This ensures that only those of a certain age can access these books, thus preventing younger children from reading them. These are viable options to keep offensive books out of children's hands and prevent them from reading material you'd rather they avoid.

People hold diverse perspectives on censorship. Some contend that certain movies, books, newspapers, etc., contain subject matter inappropriate for some viewers, and that writers should limit their content on certain topics or refrain from addressing them altogether. Others uphold the principle of freedom of speech, believing that individuals have the right to express their opinions on any topic, whether they consider it true or important. Additionally, some acknowledge that while there are writings that should not have been published, they have no control over it, and what is offensive to some may be acceptable to others. I recognize that there are stories with inappropriate content. However, I understand that even if I find a subject unfit or useless, others may not. Everyone has unique beliefs. If people could control the books, magazines, newspapers, and movies in libraries, @PERSON1's statement, 'We would have no books left on the shelf for any of us', would ring true. Certain media, regardless of the subject or its perceived inappropriateness, can be beneficial and interesting to specific individuals, as long as they are of an appropriate age. If a story is solely about drugs, sex, alcohol, and violence with no redeeming value, I believe it should be removed from the shelf. We can't predict who might access such material, and it could be a child. While I believe we shouldn't remove anything that could be useful to someone, there is a limit to what should be made available.

Whatever happened to using books and films purely for entertainment? Why are we now cautious about what our children select from the library shelves? Contemporary society has transformed our perception of entertainment sources. Books are now regarded with suspicion, and once - innocuous movies and magazines are rife with inappropriate material. Music, once a beautiful art form, now often features mindless lyrics filled with curses and other offensive content when you turn on the radio. Should libraries exercise caution when lending materials that are inappropriate for harmless entertainment? There was once a young, shy but intelligent girl, aged fourteen or fifteen, who loved reading and music. She used books as her companions and visited the library daily for a new story. One day, she discovered a well - worn book on the top shelf of the fiction section. Its spine was split, and some pages were nearly detached. Intrigued, she picked it up and flipped through the pages. Her innocent mind was exposed to a world she was unfamiliar with. After reading the book, she felt guilty. It was a harmful book with a negative message, and she now knew things no one at her age should. So, why wasn't there a warning? The difference between writing something offensive and being offensive is that the writer usually doesn't intend to be hurtful. The author likely intended the work to be enjoyed playfully. However, when we encounter disturbing content in a book or magazine, we can simply put it down. The real concern is about our children. How can we protect them from offensive literature? And what about music and movies? Recall the old black - and - white films. Regardless of the plot, the leading characters always fell in love in the end. The screen would go black after a kiss. There are still movies with positive messages, but what about the others? Many blockbusters feature violence, racism, and sexual content. Going to the movies should be fun, but where does the line get drawn? What if a young boy checks out such a movie from the library for a sleepover with friends? How can we keep this kind of material away from them? Libraries should exercise great caution when labeling books, movies, and magazines. Librarians should ensure that the materials children borrow are age - appropriate. They should also check movie ratings and restrict access for certain age groups. Parents should also be vigilant when allowing their children to go to the movies. They should ensure their children watch something positive. While I don't think libraries should remove certain materials from their shelves, we should be discerning about what we read and watch. We can use the internet to read reviews and decide whether a book or movie is worth engaging with. Have fun, but stay cautious.

Books, periodicals, and music should be removed if they contain content offensive to an individual or a child. Literature, magazines, and music can stimulate a child's or an adult's vivid imagination, leading them to believe certain actions are acceptable as they mature. All materials that are misused should be disposed of in a place where neither children nor adults can access them. I contend that such content can negatively influence people as they grow, or lead adults to misjudge the propriety of certain behaviors. Books and music that lack positive utility should be removed. Magazines and books with no substantial value, such as those containing pornographic or inappropriate content, should be taken off the shelves. Both children and adults possess fertile imaginations, which can sometimes result in harm to others, including family members. Books, magazines, and music are intended to inspire, yet they can also be a distraction. Unknowingly, one may hurt loved ones due to what they see, read, or hear. These can have a profound impact on individuals. The materials one acquires, such as books, magazines, and music, if unhelpful and causing more problems in life, should be removed from the market. People sometimes purchase these items because of the alluring images they contain. Another reason for removing them from the shelves is the potential negative influence they can have through visual, auditory, and textual content. All these are detrimental to anyone exposed to them. I firmly believe that books, magazines, and music that offer no intellectual or moral benefit should be removed as they do not contribute positively to the mind. Moreover, items with no constructive use are of no value. In my view, trashy books and music can even lead a person to contemplate suicide or engage in reckless behavior that they will later regret. This is why none of these materials are beneficial to either a person or a child. In conclusion, non - useful books, magazines, and music should be removed from the shelves, and materials that enhance mental development should be provided. Items that do not contribute to a person's mental well - being should be discarded. These inappropriate materials can lead to instability in life and cause individuals to make wrong decisions that result in failure. Finally, all unresourceful books, magazines, and music should be put away.

I firmly oppose the notion of removing books, music, movies, or magazines from library shelves simply because they are deemed offensive. Firstly, one must consider what is offensive to the majority and who should have the authority to determine whether content should be censored. Individuals should have the autonomy to decide whether to access an item from a shelf, as they may not find it offensive at all. As a parent, one has the right to restrict their children from accessing certain materials, but removing such items from the shelves restricts others who may find the content acceptable. Offensive content can range from profanity to extreme violence. Some individuals may not be bothered by a few expletives or mild violence, while others find it highly offensive. In my personal experience, I do not consider mild swearing offensive, but I am aware that some people are extremely sensitive to even the slightest profanity. Many contemporary movies contain mildly offensive content, but this is often done in a satirical manner. While this may further offend some, viewers have the option not to watch these movies. It ultimately depends on an individual's upbringing and personal moral compass. It is either an individual's or a parent's responsibility to assess the appropriateness of a book or movie's content. Parents often argue that children are too young to make such judgments, which is valid. Consequently, most children's movies and books are carefully curated to avoid content that may be too mature for them. As individuals grow older, they are better equipped to make decisions about what to read or watch, as they have likely been exposed to similar ideas in their daily lives. The decision boils down to the target audience and the appropriateness of the content for their age. The idea of removing these materials from library shelves would be disastrous. School reading lists would have to be significantly reduced due to parental objections, depriving children of valuable knowledge found in literature. A person might visit a library to rent their favorite horror movie, only to find it missing because a few individuals found it offensive. If one person's disapproval led to the removal of items, libraries would be virtually empty, as every item is likely to have at least one detractor. I once read *To Kill a Mockingbird*, and our teacher informed us that it had been banned in another state because a few parents objected to certain aspects of the book. This classic piece of literature contains numerous valuable lessons and ideas. These parents sought to ban the book from all schools and libraries nationwide, which would be a violation of others' freedom of speech. Parents can voice their opinions and restrict their own children from reading the book, but they should not deny others the opportunity. Removing books from the shelves would also eliminate the ideas they contain. Literature, movies, and other forms of media shape a culture. Throughout history, many social movements have been sparked by literature, which has had a profound impact on society. Censorship would erode a part of our cultural heritage, which would be devastating. One should reflect on their own sensitivities and then try to understand the perspective of those who do not find the same content offensive. It is important to consider whether it is justifiable to deprive everyone of access to certain materials. Almost everything can be considered offensive to someone, but it is each individual's responsibility to determine what is appropriate for themselves or their children. Library shelves should remain stocked with a diverse range of books, movies, music, and magazines, as this is an essential expression of freedom of speech, which is integral to our country and culture.

Censorship in libraries has its merits in certain aspects. Bibliophiles should have access to a diverse array of literary works. Offensive content can vary widely; for example, a book about [specific topic] or the historical mistreatment of indigenous people. However, in contemporary society, almost anything can be perceived as offensive, which is rather absurd. Inevitably, there will always be something that someone finds objectionable. In my personal encounter with such a situation, it did not particularly bother me. Once, while browsing in a library, I came across a paragraph in a book that contained the derogatory term 'nigger,' which I found mildly offensive. This term is highly inappropriate and disrespectful. Different individuals have diverse preferences for books, movies, magazines, etc. Some of the most renowned movies of all time are likely to be offensive to certain people in some way. What one person finds offensive, another may not. For instance, my aunt finds certain magazines offensive because of the swimsuit models used for advertising new swimsuits or the promotion of alcoholic beverages. In general, nearly everything can be offensive to someone. If all offensive materials were to be removed, there would be very few books, movies, etc. left, and this would be a great loss for the cultural and intellectual landscape.

Individuals should possess the right to engage with any form of media, whether it be through listening, reading, or watching. The choice of what to read, view, or listen to is a personal one. Removing offensive movies or books will not change an individual's preferences; they will simply seek such content elsewhere. People have the entitlement to access materials that they believe are beneficial to them. If others find certain content offensive, that is a matter of personal perception. Each person has the right to make their own decisions in this regard. I am of the opinion that restricting someone's access to certain media will only increase their desire to engage with it. Removing offensive books, music, movies, and magazines will not address the issue of offensive content in society; it will merely conceal it. Such removal will not prevent people from being exposed to offensive material; it will only limit their access in libraries. Every form of media, including books, music, and movies, is likely to be offensive to someone. If all offensive content were removed, there would be little left to read or watch. This is an issue that society must learn to manage. Therefore, I do not support censorship in libraries. Censorship not only infringes on our right to access the media of our choice but also eliminates a significant portion of available content, as almost every book can be considered offensive to someone. Everyone has their own sensitivities, and removing all potentially offensive books would leave libraries virtually empty.

I do not believe that specific books should be removed from library shelves. There are numerous aspects of society that can be perceived as offensive, including gangs, politics, race, and even the schools that young children attend. I understand the desire of parents to protect their children, but it is impossible to shield them from everything. In inner - city areas, gangs often deface trains, buildings, and other public property with vulgar language. One cannot simply 'take this off the shelf' as it is a real - world issue. Politics can be extremely divisive, especially during presidential elections when candidates often resort to personal attacks, including remarks about a candidate's race and other personal details. Children are exposed to this through television. Racial conflicts are a global problem, with people engaging in violence based on skin color. It is an ongoing battle that shows no sign of resolution and is likely to worsen. While I cannot speak for all schools, my own school has its share of problems, such as young children using profanity, older students engaging in physical altercations, and students who strive for academic excellence being bullied. It is unrealistic to shield children from these issues indefinitely. Eventually, they will become aware of these problems. Instead of removing books from the shelves, parents should keep their children away from dangerous environments. Reading about these problems in a book is a safer alternative than experiencing them firsthand in the real world. Parents must prepare their children for the challenges ahead. Failing to do so may result in their children being more severely affected by these issues than by the mild language found in books, magazines, or movies.

In the novel Fahrenheit @NUM1, all books are incinerated regardless of their content, and the populace perpetually endures melancholy and despondency regarding every aspect of life. Books constitute an indispensable component of our existence. Certain materials indeed necessitate censorship as they might affront individuals who already grapple with self - identity, and such content could exacerbate their distress. Nevertheless, there exist some books that are censored with little or no justifiable cause. A single impolite or misconstrued word might lead to the unwarranted censorship of a book. When employed appropriately, censorship holds significance for libraries. We rely on books for diverse purposes, from educational pursuits to mere pastime. Music has accompanied humanity since time immemorial. Movies depict the vicissitudes of life. Magazines apprise us of novel and engaging developments. These entities have become as vital to us as clothing and sustenance. Simply eliminating them would render the world a gloomier abode. Some of these elements can inadvertently offend people. Katherine Paterson posits that if one has the prerogative to eliminate an offensive book, then everyone can do the same, and soon all books will vanish. We can strive to be amiable to all, yet at some juncture, something will invariably insult someone, regardless of our actions or words. Should we discard everything for this reason?

What constitutes censorship? Many would assert that it is a book devoid of profanity or a movie free from racial prejudice. In my perspective, censorship equates to obfuscating the truth. I contend that movies or books should not be removed from circulation merely because some individuals find them offensive. When a book employs a profanity to convey anger or simply utilizes the word, I deem it acceptable, as this is what we commonly encounter in the real world. I am cognizant that some individuals may not have been exposed to vulgar language during their upbringing, but a significant portion of us have. Regarding movies, I believe that if parents have reservations about their children viewing inappropriate or offensive content, they should exercise parental discretion and prohibit their children from watching. This is the crux of the problem with contemporary society; people are reluctant to assume responsibility for the misfortunes in their lives. Individuals resort to censorship as a means to project an image of being a conscientious parent or to feel entitled to a fault - free world. When someone deems a movie or book to have crossed the line in terms of race, censorship becomes a prevalent topic. Many individuals are sensitive about their race or nationality being misrepresented. It is ironic that members of a particular race may use derogatory terms among themselves, yet when such language appears in a book, it is labeled as racism. Similarly, when a certain race is portrayed in a movie in a manner that makes them uncomfortable, the movie is branded as racist. I opine that if people object to something, they should exclude it from their own lives. Excessive individuals attempt to exert control through censorship. For years, there has been a push to censor school - assigned books due to inappropriate language. Instead of focusing on censoring books, perhaps the focus should be on the school environment. I am aware that students in school frequently use vulgar language, often more egregiously than what is found in the books they read. If adults recognized that it is their children who require guidance rather than the books, censorship would not have become such a contentious issue. People need to understand that censoring books or movies does not eradicate offensive language or inappropriate imagery; it merely conceals them.

Removing books from library shelves because one person deems them offensive? I find this practice unjust. This reflects the opinion of a single individual, and I am certain that others hold different views. Just because one person believes a book is offensive and should be removed does not imply that a child cannot glean knowledge from it. Moreover, music, movies, and magazines are readily accessible elsewhere, so why is it unacceptable to have them in a library? A substantial number of children visit libraries to obtain books for their schoolwork. If people remove the books they need, how are they supposed to complete their assignments? I am confident that some individuals would argue that certain books are not suitable for children at their current stage of learning. However, we will inevitably encounter such knowledge at some point, so why not now? Removing music from libraries is also ill - advised. Children can easily access music on the internet, and many do so in ways that may lead to trouble. Therefore, having music in libraries provides them with a safe and free means of access. Magazines can be purchased at stores, but many children may lack the financial means to buy them. Thus, having magazines in libraries offers them an opportunity to peruse them. As long as the content is appropriate for children, I see no harm in libraries providing these materials. In conclusion, I believe that removing books, music, magazines, and movies from libraries is not a prudent decision. Perhaps libraries could establish an adult - only section. If someone suggests that a book belongs in this section, librarians can review it to determine its suitability. While some content may need to be removed, excessive censorship would undermine the essence of a library.

I opine that if content is offensive, it should not be accessible to children until they reach an age where they can comprehend and process it. I advocate for the removal of such content from public shelves or its segregation. This is because offensive material can be harmful and inappropriate for younger audiences, and its removal can prevent potential negative impacts. I believe that magazines can be stored separately or placed in dedicated sections. Similarly, music and movies can be organized into distinct areas. Internet access can be restricted to certain websites. Fortunately, in our society, there are adults who can prevent children from being exposed to inappropriate content. There are also individuals who can monitor children and inform them when something is unsuitable for their age. In my view, preventing children's exposure to offensive material is a straightforward task. By removing or segregating such content, we can eliminate concerns about whether our children are accessing it. In conclusion, taking proactive measures to censor offensive content in libraries is a responsible approach to safeguarding the well - being of young readers.

Dear Newspaper, I wish to commence by stating that books, music, movies, magazines, and other media in libraries are highly beneficial for children. It is commendable that children have a place to visit during their leisure time, whether they seek entertainment or a quiet space to read. However, certain materials are inappropriate for young children and adolescents. In high school, merely traversing the hallways can expose one to more information than one might desire. Much of this information may be inappropriate, and when one enters the library, it sometimes appears as if the library is promoting drugs, alcohol, and sexual content. Books about drugs can be acceptable to a certain degree, particularly when they pertain to medicinal use. However, when they glorify drugs as a means to alleviate pain and enhance well - being, it crosses the line. Our children and future generations do not need to be exposed to such ideas. The same principle applies to alcohol. Alcohol is ubiquitous, and children are engaging in underage drinking at an early age, largely due to the promotion of alcohol in movies, music, and books. Our children should learn about the perils of alcohol, not how to become intoxicated and the behaviors associated with drunkenness. Advertisements are particularly detrimental to children, especially when they are prominently displayed on billboards and magazine covers. Children should not be exposed to such content at a young age. Instead, they should be encouraged to engage in outdoor activities, participate in sports, spend time with family, and ride bicycles. I believe that offensive materials should be removed from libraries. Perhaps it is in the best interest of our children to have such content removed from the shelves, as it may contribute to their physical and mental well - being, allowing them to lead healthier and longer lives without being influenced by the allure of drugs and alcohol. Sincerely, @PERSON1.

I am dispatching this letter to convey my perspectives on censorship in libraries. Some individuals contend that books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are objectionable. While these might be offensive to them, they may not be so to others. Thus, one must consider not only their own viewpoint but also those of others. I opine that such items should not be removed from the shelves. Everyone holds a distinct perspective; for instance, my mother adores vampire books and movies, whereas I prefer tragedies. Evidently, everyone has different preferences. They also need to reflect on the fact that books from @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @NUM1, @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @NUM2, etc., are offensive to some. Are we also going to remove those books? I mean, if we were to eliminate books, music, movies, magazines, etc., due to their offensiveness, we would be left with none. Everyone deems something offensive; some may find the same thing offensive, while others may find different things so. We should not remove books, music, movies, magazines, etc., from the shelves. I comprehend that people do not want their children to view or listen to such content. However, it is a part of life. One cannot remove everything to please a single person, as it may anger another.

Libraries typically serve as a secure and tranquil haven where individuals can sit, savor a cup of coffee, and peruse a book or magazine, browse the internet, or listen to their favorite music. Nevertheless, some individuals do not utilize it in this manner. They perceive it as an opportunity to engage in frivolous behavior and disrespect others who are seeking some personal time, whether their children are away or they have had a difficult day and wish to regroup and prepare for the next day. We then question why people choose to sit in a library to read. Why can't they simply borrow a book, CD, or magazine and take it home? Why do people consider it such a significant matter to be able to borrow books, magazines, music, and movies from the library? I fail to understand the significance of this! Most counties possess a public library, which implies that they welcome anyone interested in accessing their resources. Indeed, I can understand libraries requiring borrowers to sign a letter or document, providing personal information such as a telephone number, address, or credit card number. The letter would stipulate the duration for which they can retain the book and the necessity to return it by a specific date; otherwise, they must renew it to avoid being accused of theft if they wish to keep it for a longer period. Most places impose what are known as late fees. Typically, if someone incurs a late fee, they are unlikely to return the book as they do not want to pay it. Therefore, I believe that by obtaining their credit card number, the library can continue to charge their account to recover the late fees. This is because they may simply ignore phone calls or discard the letter received from the library in the mail. I am aware that our school library at @ORGANIZATION1 has consistently faced challenges in retrieving books and collecting late fees. This issue can sometimes be an endless cycle with certain individuals, as some simply do not care. The internet presents a slightly different scenario, as not everyone can afford to have internet access at home. I am not writing this letter to complain or be bothersome; rather, I am attempting to share some of my ideas to ensure the smooth operation of libraries and prevent them from becoming disorganized. In my opinion, these ideas are viable, and I believe that we can make effective use of libraries in this county and @LOCATION1.

People encounter offensive things on a daily basis; it is an inevitable aspect of life. Some individuals have valid reasons to feel offended, yet they are unable to prevent it from occurring. This phenomenon has persisted for thousands of years, and people have gradually learned to cope with it. Therefore, I firmly believe that books and other materials deemed offensive should not be removed solely because they offend someone, as doing so may offend others. What I am attempting to convey is that regardless of the circumstances, not everyone will be satisfied. Life is characterized by a diverse society and a range of emotions, so it is impossible for everyone to agree on the same matters. Moreover, it should be the prerogative of the library to decide whether to remove certain materials, as they have invested in them and have the right to allow members of society to view, read, or listen to them. That being said, I believe that libraries should strive to minimize the presence of certain offensive materials, such as those related to racism. Racism continues to have a significant impact on the country today and will remain an ongoing issue in the @CAPS1. In conclusion, I believe that libraries have the right to possess books or movies that are somewhat offensive. As I mentioned earlier, everyone encounters such situations at some point, and it is impossible to please everyone. Additionally, some of this material is likely to be educational, teaching us about the history of @LOCATION1, @CAPS1, etc., rather than being simply racist or offensive, as many tend to assume. Everyone needs to move beyond the offensive aspect and reach a level of understanding where we can see eye to eye. After all, we are all equal, despite our differences in appearance and culture.

Libraries are designed to accommodate everyone, from children to adults. There may be certain items that should not be present in specific areas or in the library at all. Given that libraries house books for all age groups, there may or may not be some materials in those areas that are inappropriate for certain individuals to view, let alone be present in the first place. Children of any age can pick up materials that may contain offensive content or information that they should not be exposed to. I believe that libraries should only stock materials that are suitable for all age groups. This is my opinion regarding why libraries should only contain materials with appropriate images and language for all age groups. One cannot predict what one's own or someone else's child may pick up and read or hear. The best course of action is to ensure that all materials are appropriate and nothing else.

Should certain books, movies, and magazines be removed from library bookshelves if they are deemed offensive? I firmly believe that libraries should eliminate offensive materials. Libraries are large public institutions that disseminate knowledge and entertainment to vast numbers of people seeking to expand their intellectual horizons. Throughout @LOCATION1 and other countries, there exist libraries that house offensive content. I am strongly in favor of discarding these offensive items because young children may pick them up, some individuals may be influenced to engage in foolish activities they have learned from them, and some people may steal these items for personal use. Libraries are invaluable resources that attract diverse groups of people who come to enjoy, relax, and contemplate. Currently, libraries across the globe possess offensive materials that should be removed from their shelves. Young children and their parents visit the library as it is an excellent means of relieving stress and facilitating children's learning. Suppose there are materials that are unsuitable for children, and they pick them up and start reading. Before you know it, your children will acquire that type of knowledge, and you will be powerless to prevent it. Offensive materials are often in the vicinity of young children, and parents may be unaware. Children may adopt offensive language or discuss it at school, and this material may spread. Such materials in the library can harm children's minds by indoctrinating them. Teenagers are at an age where they may engage in regrettable actions. They often visit the library to meet friends or commence their homework. An immature individual may spot a book and begin reading it. Subsequently, they may find it extremely amusing and attempt to replicate it at home, resulting in serious injury. Teens can be easily influenced by anything, and unfortunately, this influence can originate in the library. There are also individuals who enter a library and steal offensive materials for themselves. Such people are immature and pose a genuine problem for the library. Once they obtain the item, they may post it on the internet, exposing it to the entire world. Offensive materials can be easily stolen from a library; if these items were not present, troublemakers would have nothing to steal. Libraries are intended for diverse individuals who wish to learn and share their newly acquired knowledge with others. Libraries offer the most exceptional resources that any place could possess. I do not want such a wonderful resource to be tainted by these obscene materials. Therefore, I firmly believe that certain offensive materials, such as books, magazines, movies, and music, should be removed from libraries.

Some individuals contend that specific materials, including books, movies, magazines, and so forth, ought to be removed from the shelves if they are deemed offensive. Nevertheless, I maintain that they should not be removed. People possess sufficient maturity to handle offensive material. The majority of individuals borrow books or movies they have heard about, so generally, they are aware that what they are reading might be offensive. Instead of removing the offensive material, a warning should be issued to inform readers that what they are borrowing is considered offensive.  In contemporary times, people are mature enough to read offensive material. We encounter various types of offensive material daily. For instance, when we watch the news, we often see numerous offensive pictures or videos. There are also numerous news stories that many people find offensive. When an individual borrows an offensive book, they do so out of their own volition. Libraries should not deprive a reader of the right to read what they desire.  Prior to borrowing a book or movie, individuals should conduct research to ensure they are comfortable with what they are obtaining. This can prevent numerous problems. For example, suppose a young reader notices a book that appears interesting. If they do not peruse it a bit and simply take it home, they may later discover that it contains offensive material. However, if they read a brief synopsis before borrowing it, they will learn that it contains offensive material and can then decide whether they still wish to read it.  There are numerous ways libraries can prevent children or other individuals lacking the maturity to view offensive material from accessing it. They can affix a warning label to the book or movie to inform people that the particular item is considered offensive. Libraries could even impose an age limit on borrowing offensive material. Either of these measures could be an effective means of ensuring that only mature individuals borrow anything deemed offensive.  Libraries should not be required to remove books, music, movies, magazines, etc., that contain offensive material from the shelves. If an individual wishes to borrow an offensive book, they should be permitted to do so and read it. Additionally, people should be intelligent enough to research whatever item they are borrowing beforehand so they can be aware of the offensive material. However, to simplify matters, libraries could simply attach a warning label to offensive material to deter some people from reading it.

I opine that censorship in libraries today is not a significant issue. However, many would dissent from this view. Books and movies can serve as highly valuable resources for individuals of all ages. They can furnish us with facts about a particular topic that we may not discover elsewhere. Everyone has their own conception of what is offensive. I believe that it is not solely the library's responsibility to rate books, movies, and magazines as offensive; it also falls upon the users of these resources.  For numerous children, regardless of age, they borrow books from a library primarily for two reasons: entertainment and academic projects. Censoring a book from a teenager or child is akin to issuing an invitation to explore its contents. Those who engage in recreational reading typically adhere to a single genre. If someone wishes to borrow a book that is inappropriate for them, the librarian or teacher would restrict their access to it. In the case of academic projects, such as for school, it would depend on the librarian to censor the book for a child. However, books are not rated in the same manner as movies. Thus, it truly depends on the purpose of the book and the maturity of the person borrowing it. If they believe it would be inappropriate for some, they could recommend censoring it.  Movies and books differ in numerous respects. Books enable you to form a mental description and image of what you are reading. Movies, conversely, present a visual image directly before your eyes. No matter how gruesome or repugnant a description a book may offer, it still pales in comparison to the visual depiction of a video. Movies are currently rated according to the age of the viewer, and the reasons for the rating are provided. Movies rated above a certain level are typically not stocked in libraries. They may still be censored if they create an excessively repugnant image, but this is at the discretion of the viewer.  Music is an integral part of our lives, and without it, the world would be a vastly different place. Everyone has a preference for a particular genre of music and usually adheres to it. Music, like movies, is also rated based on the content of the song. If it contains one or two words that should be censored, it is likely already labeled 'explicit'. I believe that music, similar to movies, should not be subject to censorship, as it is already rated accordingly.  Some books, magazines, and movies contain harsh realities about the past of our world and are too disturbing for some. Although these events belong to our past, they remain highly significant in our present. Books can be a magical realm for children and adults alike, allowing them to create their own worlds. Censoring a book, movie, or magazine would deprive someone of the opportunity to enjoy life a little more during that brief moment.

My stance on this matter is that it is unjust. This is an extremely intriguing question, and I shall elucidate the rationale behind my perspective. I am both in favor of and opposed to it.  Certainly, individuals have diverse preferences, and others may not concur. This is how society functions. If a parent is strolling through the mall with their child and enters a music store where the music contains profanity, I would not want my child to be exposed to such content. This is precisely what is meant by removing something when it offends someone. I wholeheartedly concur with this. Take cigarettes, for example. Children enter a store to purchase candy, and when they go to pay, they are confronted with a wall full of tobacco products. Once again, I would advocate for removing such items from the shelves.  However, implementing such measures would give rise to numerous conflicts. Everyone has distinct tastes, so removing items that some find offensive is likely to offend others. This applies to individuals of all ages.  Now, let me present my opposing view. I would be extremely incensed if I held a particular item in high regard, only to discover that someone was offended by it and had it removed from public access. This would merely create problems for everyone and exacerbate the situation. We all have our opinions and preferences, and we must learn to accept that not everyone will share our views. We need to be resilient and accept things that we may not like.  In conclusion, I am ambivalent on this subject. I can appreciate both perspectives as there are merits and drawbacks to each. People must come to terms with the fact that they will encounter things they find objectionable in life. It is an inevitable part of the human experience.

I am of the opinion that certain materials should not be removed if they are deemed inappropriate. There are several compelling reasons to support this view.  Firstly, some libraries do not carry certain genres of books. For example, one library may offer action novels but lack thrillers, while another may have thrillers but no action books. If certain materials were removed from public libraries due to censorship, people would have to resort to online sources or specialized stores to access them.  Secondly, children are unlikely to be interested in inappropriate books unless they have obtained parental approval. If such materials remain on the shelves, an age restriction could be imposed, except when parents allow their children to borrow them without prior consent. While this would make the library more child - friendly, a book should not be withheld from a child solely because of a few offensive words.  Lastly, some adults would be displeased if certain books were removed. Some books that are intended for a more mature audience are better off remaining in the library. If these books were removed, adults would have to search for them online.  In my view, censorship will not yield any positive results. If this trend continues, it could reach a point where libraries would have to close their doors. Therefore, we should not allow censorship to dominate our libraries.

Censorship, to the majority of people, signifies far more than an ordinary three - syllable word. It implies relinquishing the right to express and think as one desires. To most, this concept is unappealing. When an individual is censored, they are essentially forfeiting the right to freedom of speech. In this essay, I will expound upon three disadvantages of censorship in libraries.  One primary reason censorship should not be permitted in libraries is the infringement of freedom of speech. Decades ago, when the right to free speech was established, the idea of censorship was not part of the plan. As citizens, it is our entitlement to speak and write freely, without fear of repercussions, regardless of whether the material is offensive or inoffensive. We should recognize that everyone is unique and not all opinions will align. Does this mean that just because one person finds something offensive, an item should be removed from the shelves? Certainly not. Freedom of speech is our birthright, and we should be allowed to express or write anything without being censored.  Author Katherine Paterson astutely observes, '...But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This simply means that if one person has the right to remove a book they dislike, then everyone has that right. As previously mentioned, it is illogical to remove a book just because one person finds it offensive. If this were the case, each of us could find multiple books in the library that we find offensive, and eventually, there would be no books left on the shelves.  Another drawback of censorship in libraries is the loss of perspective and learning that books offer. As an enthusiastic reader, I can attest to the wealth of vocabulary and new knowledge I gain from reading a single book. Recently, I read the book [Book Title]. Initially, I developed a strong aversion to the main character, and later realized the book was highly offensive. However, through reading it, I gained valuable insights into a particular aspect of life that I knew nothing about.  In conclusion, censorship in libraries is a flawed concept. When one is censored, they lose their right to freedom of speech, access to a wide range of books, and the opportunity to learn from diverse perspectives. I hope this essay has convinced you or at least informed you about the disadvantages of censorship in libraries.

Is there an adequate level of censorship in our libraries? Have you ever encountered a vulgar or offensive book in your library and wished that no children had ever perused it? Well, such a situation should never occur. If a book or any other material is offensive, then it should be placed in a separate area of the library where only adults can access it. Apart from that section, there should not be any offensive or vulgar materials that children or even early teenagers should be able to view. Almost daily, children and teenagers have access to offensive and vulgar materials that could have detrimental effects on them. Perhaps if they do not encounter these offensive materials when they are young, they will be less likely to engage in or utilize some of the things they see or read. For example, when teenagers read about people using drugs, it could influence them to partake in such activities as well. The materials might not have an immediate impact, but later on, it could have a significant effect on them. The youth is what will be governing this country when we are old. So, we need to do our part and remove offensive and vulgar materials from the reach of our children and teenagers. I do not want my children to read some of the things I read when I was young. That is why I believe there should be censorship in every library.

I opine that every book in the world should be available on the shelves. For if a book is offensive, one can simply refrain from reading it. It is far better if one can freely access any book one desires. And if a library does not possess a particular book, then one presumably has to obtain it elsewhere. However, some individuals would not go through all that trouble for a single book. This implies that they will not acquire as much knowledge as they intended or could have. We need intelligent individuals to reach their full potential and acquire as much knowledge as they desire and are capable of. Nevertheless, books are books, and not everyone reads a large number of them. Suppose one wishes to learn about a truck. What does one do? One either finds a book about it, searches online, or consults someone with knowledge. How would anyone know anything about it if the person who built the truck did not write a book detailing it? One would have to disassemble the truck and discover the information oneself, which is by no means easy. And if one makes a mistake, that is not favorable. But if one has a book to refer to, it generally simplifies matters significantly. This is one of the reasons why every book should be on the shelf. So that if one needs to learn something and wishes to expand their knowledge, they can read about it and uncover what they want to know. Reading is one of the most effective ways to find the information one seeks, ensuring that one is not misled. Additionally, books are simply enjoyable to read. All movies should also be accessible because everyone has the right to watch any movie they desire, unless they are underage and require parental consent. If a movie is offensive, one can choose not to watch it. Magazines are also valuable. I read numerous magazines and can find a wealth of information on various topics. Therefore, they are indeed beneficial.

Do I hold the belief that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed due to their offensive nature? No, I do not. My perspective on the diverse range of items found in our libraries is positive. The majority of them contain highly useful information. Some individuals may dislike certain things because of their content, but much of it is historical in nature. One cannot alter history. If someone dislikes a book, movie, or magazine, they should simply refrain from engaging with it. I have found the materials in our libraries to be extremely helpful for numerous projects. If we need to learn about slaves or slavery, we can turn to our library. Some people may have different views on this, but that is the reality. We can only learn from the mistakes of the past. I suggest that if one does not like the appearance of a book's cover, they should look for something more appealing. I have not encountered anything in our library that I find offensive or even objectionable. They have books on a wide variety of subjects. Some of the content may be controversial, but for the most part, it is all valuable information. They discuss history, guns, drugs, wars, and all sorts of other historical details. There are even books about things that may not be entirely true. I believe that some people overreact to certain things. If one does not like a book or movie, they should not obtain it. Examine the cover, and if it seems interesting, then go ahead. But if not, do not waste time complaining about it, as things can quickly get out of hand. That is my opinion on books, movies, magazines, etc., in our libraries. Generally, they seem very useful, but others may hold different viewpoints.

I contend that no books should be removed from the shelves. Certain materials may be offensive to some individuals, but others may require these books for research, projects, etc. People need to read to comprehend why some individuals consider certain things offensive to others. Every book should be available on the shelves of a public library. Everyone has the freedom to make their own choices; let them determine if a book is offensive to them and others. Perhaps an author has written a book about gangsters and their children. Maybe the author intended to provide an inside look into someone's life. We live in a highly diverse world, and there will inevitably be different perspectives. The author could be writing the book to illustrate what a child endured during a particular period of life, including killings and violence. This should not be considered offensive simply because it involves such topics. Reading the book should allow one to understand how the child grew up. The book could even change the minds of some parents who are involved in gangs. It could enable them to realize how their actions will impact their child's future. I believe the same principle applies to movies and magazines. Through reading magazines and watching movies, one can gain valuable insights. Suppose one is a member of a gang. By watching movies and reading, one would discover the consequences of gang involvement, which could potentially change one's perspective. These books, movies, and magazines can show what lies ahead. Perhaps directors and writers create such content to demonstrate the potential outcomes of continuing down a path of gang involvement and harmful associations. Why should certain individuals have the authority to decide if a book, movie, magazine, etc., is offensive to some but not others? I believe the only solution is to leave every book on the public library shelves. Let the patrons of the library decide what is appropriate or offensive for them to read. Even if libraries make a decision, someone is bound to be dissatisfied. I do not think there is any way to resolve this issue other than allowing people to read and make their own judgments. If someone likes a book, that is great; if not, they can simply refrain from reading it again or return it. No one can determine right from wrong for someone else; only an individual can make that decision for themselves.

Some children remove books from the shelves that some elderly individuals are unable to read nowadays. Some individuals take books from the shelves, damage them, and even tear out pages. This behavior not only disrupts the availability of these books for others but also undermines the integrity of the library's collection. It is essential that we instill in children the importance of respecting library materials. By doing so, we can ensure that everyone has equal access to the knowledge and resources that libraries offer. We should also encourage children to report any damaged books they come across so that the library staff can take appropriate action. In conclusion, it is our collective responsibility to protect and preserve the library's collection for the benefit of all.

Greetings @ORGANIZATION1, I am penning this correspondence to discuss the matter of censorship within libraries. Libraries possess an abundance of materials containing offensive language and imagery. I hold a comprehensive perspective on this subject. My stance is that if censorship is implemented in libraries, then television should also be censored. I have deaf parents, thus we always have captions enabled at home. Daily, I encounter uncensored profanity and unfiltered images. Moreover, the current youth are more inclined to watch television than utilize libraries. Therefore, why not censor television? I witness content on television that I would never encounter in a library. In conclusion, I firmly believe that libraries should not censor their materials as students will inevitably discover such content elsewhere. There are numerous other environments that are far more detrimental. For instance, crime scenes are replete with blood and gore, whereas libraries only contain offensive language. These are my viewpoints, and others may differ.

Renowned author Katherine Paterson once remarked, 'All of us can conceive of a book we hope no child will ever retrieve from the shelf - that work I detest - then you, too, possess the same right, as does everyone else. And then, there will be no books left on the shelves for anyone.' I surmise that she intended to convey that certain books should not be readily accessible to children. I wholeheartedly concur with her assertion. I once perused a book with highly mature content. It was extremely vulgar and inappropriate for my age and level of maturity. There are numerous such books in circulation, and we must shield them from the children in our society. They are too young to be exposed to adult themes such as war, violence, sex, drugs, and various other topics. By removing these mature books and other forms of media from library shelves, our children will lead more fulfilling lives. There will be a reduction in teenage pregnancies, drug usage, and other societal issues. Children will exhibit better behavior as they will be less influenced by such media. However, I do not advocate for the complete eradication of these books. Instead, we should restrict their availability in libraries. Individuals who wish to read such books should seek them elsewhere. A straightforward solution to this problem is to impose an age limit on books and media with mature content and allocate them to a separate section in libraries or a dedicated store. A distinguished author emphasized that children should not be exposed to adult content in the media. Nevertheless, she also acknowledged that individuals have the right to consume such media. Hence, an age limit is necessary for this type of content. For now, if the content is unsuitable or offensive to you, simply refrain from engaging with it.

At some juncture in our lives, we have all visited a library. Have you ever browsed through the shelves and encountered something that you found offensive or disagreed with? What if you had the opportunity to permanently remove it from the shelves? Alternatively, what if someone else had the power to make that decision? Would you permit them to do so? In my view, I would firmly decline. No one has the right to remove reading materials from the shelves merely because it may be offensive to them or their way of life. I contend that if you dislike something, simply avoid it; it is as straightforward as that. For example, if you are an enthusiast of rap or hip - hop culture, and someone finds it offensive, would you grant them the authority to deny you access to it? Conversely, would you impose such a restriction on others? Suppose you are a Christian, and an atheist deems @CAPS1 offensive or untrue and has it removed from the shelves. Does that seem fair to you? If someone dislikes a particular topic, culture, or finds it offensive, they should simply abstain from it. The crux of the matter is that if we all start removing items from the shelves, eventually, there will be nothing left. We should respect diverse cultures and ways of life and steer clear of what offends us. Would you appreciate someone removing your preferred materials from the shelves? I certainly would not, and neither should you do so to others.

In contemporary society, it appears that we are inclined to censor every aspect of life. However, one must question whether we have overstepped the boundaries. Have we crossed the line and, instead of safeguarding our children, are we impeding the progress of society as a whole? In my opinion, the censorship of literature has indeed gone too far. A library is, in essence, an invaluable resource for each generation. While it still retains its significance in some cases, when books are withheld due to the potential of offending someone, we are depriving people of the knowledge that can be gleaned from these literary works. In an attempt to appease everyone in modern society, we censor numerous elements that are considered politically incorrect. If future generations are unable to learn from these writings, they will lack the insights that we have acquired. Moreover, it must be acknowledged that history and society have never been, and likely never will be, entirely politically correct. People take offense to certain words, and as a result, some libraries remove books containing these words from their shelves. But what have we truly achieved by doing so? Have we made the world a better place by attempting to conceal a part of history? This is a debatable question. Similarly, in school, we are required to study the @CAPS1, despite the fact that it disturbs many. We must learn about it because it was a crucial chapter in history that needs to be remembered to prevent similar atrocities from occurring in the future. If we study a global event that originated in another country, should we not also confront our own historical faults? The instances of oppression and the derogatory terms that were once commonly used, which we now attempt to conceal. Has this censorship truly benefited us? No, because people will not understand the magnitude of a problem until they recognize it and are reminded of its wrongness. Napoleon once stated that history is a narrative crafted by the victors. But is victory truly sweet when our history has been rewritten? If everything that offends people is censored or removed, we will be left with nothing. If one person is allowed to determine what is acceptable, others will follow suit. It will become a trend, and people will find fault with almost anything. In essence, by censoring library materials, we are hindering the development of future generations. We are forcing them to remain ignorant of society's problems. Ultimately, we must ask ourselves if the cost of censorship is truly worth it.

When people envision a library, they typically picture a tranquil space for study and reading. Teachers utilize libraries for a multitude of purposes. They employ them to access movies on specific topics, books about particular individuals or events, and magazines for projects and to stay informed about the world beyond the classroom. So, what is my stance on the removal of offensive materials? Allow me to elaborate. Children frequently watch movies in class. While some movies may be inappropriate at times, others are highly insightful and beneficial. I believe that if a teacher pre - views a movie and deems it unsuitable for elementary school students, it should be prohibited from the school library. However, high school students are likely to have encountered more explicit content, so most movies should remain accessible in high school libraries but not in elementary ones. Books are another valuable resource when used appropriately. They aid students in history classes to learn about war heroes and past events. Nevertheless, some books should be stored behind the counter and reserved for specific classes. For example, books that provide detailed information about drugs should be removed from the shelves and placed out of general reach. If someone requires such a book for medical purposes, such as to become a doctor, they can simply request it. Magazines serve several useful functions. They are ideal for projects, especially when a computer is unavailable. They offer high - quality pictures for topics like food. Additionally, they are a popular source of entertainment. When a book is unappealing or too challenging to read, a magazine can be a suitable alternative. In reality, some materials should be retained, while others should be removed. People spend a significant amount of time in libraries for various reasons, and this will not change. Movies are an excellent form of entertainment, and this too will remain constant. Therefore, I am ambivalent about the retention or removal of offensive materials in libraries.

My perspective opposes the unrestricted dissemination of certain newspaper articles. There exist specific articles, radio broadcasts, and other media sources that graphically depict events in the news, which I deem inappropriate for certain individuals, such as younger children or those who object to being exposed to elements like biased reactions, opinions, and interpretations. The open distribution of newspaper articles and materials containing disturbing imagery should be subject to censorship. Recently, I came across photos of individuals who lost their lives during the search for @LOCATION1. I recognize that these images hold significance for interested parties, but for children who can simply glance at the newspaper on their doorstep, they may encounter horrifying visuals that some believe they should not be exposed to. Even adults may not necessarily concur with such exposure. Adults may find the news either intriguing in relation to their own interests or deeply disturbing. However, when it comes to protecting their children and limiting their exposure, it may not be advisable for kids to be exposed to such content. One day, while in the car on the way back from school, my father had just picked me up. As I typically do when entering the car, I casually switched the radio from AM to FM. Instead of the expected top - one - hundred song, I heard a woman expressing her opinion about the death of @LOCATION1 to a talk - radio show host. The show had been pre - recorded. After the woman vented her anger about the entire situation, there was a review of other calls from people who were extremely frustrated with her comments. She had earlier stated that it was wrong to kill someone, to which the talk - radio show host countered with the argument that it was acceptable for @LOCATION1 to kill thousands, but not for him to be killed. The remarks of the other callers disturbed me. Their statements were highly offensive towards the woman who had shared her feelings. They told her to leave the country and used profanity. News like the death of @LOCATION1 is not only violent in itself but also elicits highly violent reactions. Another instance when I was exposed to information that may not have been well - received by others was during an assembly at my school. We watched a video about a protest against people of @CAPS1 belief. The root of the problem was that the people of the @CAPS1 faith, who were born in @LOCATION3, were meeting with representatives to assist a poor community in @LOCATION2. Despite their efforts to help the poor and the homeless in @LOCATION2, there were people at the protest shouting at them to leave and go back to their place of origin. When people encounter such news, it can be deeply offensive. Even if it is happening on the opposite coast, it can affect individuals, especially those who do not understand the underlying conflicts that shape people's opinions and may take it very personally. This is a complex issue, yet it is still clearly wrong. I firmly believe that the material accessible to people of all ages should be censored because the currently openly - distributed content is not necessarily suitable for everyone. Some individuals may not wish to be exposed to certain topics and would prefer to avoid related news.

I contend that if a book is eligible for publication, it should rightfully be included in a library. Once a book is published, it becomes accessible to the public, and thus, there seems to be no valid reason for its exclusion from libraries. If a book is to be removed from a library's shelves, one must question why it was purchased in the first place. I fail to perceive the necessity of removing a book from a library's collection. If an individual dislikes a particular book, they are under no obligation to borrow it. In my view, only the library's proprietor should have the authority to remove a book from the shelf, as it is their establishment. However, it would be wasteful to spend money on a book only to remove it later. The general public should not have the power to remove books from libraries, as people have diverse literary preferences and viewpoints. If anyone could freely remove books, libraries would eventually be devoid of their collections. A book is an inanimate object, not a criminal, so there is no justifiable reason for its removal from libraries. If a book can be published, it should be placed in libraries. Since it has already been made available to the public through publication, there is no valid cause for it to be taken off the shelf.

I firmly believe that a magazine should not be removed from the shelves merely because someone is offended. People experience offense on a regular basis, yet one rarely witnesses them attempting to eliminate the source of their discomfort. I have previously been offended by cartoons, but I do not resort to complaining. One must simply endure the situation and continue with life. Cartman, a character from the TV show @LOCATION1, is one of the most offensive characters on that program. He employs every form of offensive language known to humanity. He ridicules all races and claims to hate everyone equally. However, it is impossible to suppress such content, just as it is impossible to transform a dog into a cat. It is also comparable to the futile attempt to eradicate racism. This is my stance on encountering offensive material.

When one enters a local library, they are confronted with a vast array of resources, including thousands of books, magazines, movies, and more. These resources come in various types and styles, encompassing fiction and non - fiction, comedy, horror, children's literature, and numerous other genres. What may not be commonly known is that some libraries house materials that are sexual, violent, or disruptive, and are inappropriate for young children. They may also possess movies and magazines of a similar nature, which can have a negative influence. When a young child enters a library, they typically expect to discover books filled with color, action, and pictures. However, during their exploration, they may stumble upon a book that is not intended for their age group and may end up being influenced by it. An inappropriate book can potentially have a detrimental impact on a child's life, as they may attempt to imitate the content in the real world, leading to poor decisions. Inappropriate movies and magazines, such as pornographic materials or pictures, and movies rated @CAPS1 or @CAPS2, should not be permitted in libraries. Such items should be sold in specialized stores, as they are intended for adult consumption only. We should strive to inspire young children to make positive choices and refrain from exposing them to negative influences. If such items are present in a home, they should be stored in a location inaccessible to children. In the current generation, many young people are preoccupied with gang violence, sex, rap music, and drugs, all of which can be found in movies, books, and songs. By removing these negative - minded items from public places like libraries and even homes, there is a possibility of positive change. Most rap songs today discuss violence, sex, or drugs, while music should ideally convey a positive message. I believe that if I encounter a book, movie, magazine, or other material on a shelf where a young person can see it, I should have the right to remove it. Society has changed, and by implementing such a change, I believe several aspects of our lives can improve. Although I am still young, I think that my teenage generation should put an end to violence and avoid being influenced by everything they see or hear. By focusing on the more important aspects of life, the world can become a significantly different place.

Censorship in libraries can have both positive and negative implications. This is because there are certain materials that one may not want their children to access, while there are others that are beneficial for them. Age demographics play a crucial role in the issue of censorship, as there are contents in books, music, movies, and magazines that are inappropriate for young children. However, if these materials are censored, children may not have the opportunity to access them even when they are older. The decision to censor should depend on the nature of the content within these media. What one person finds offensive in a book or magazine may not be offensive to another. This is why censorship can be a double - edged sword. I am certain that there are materials that may not offend me but could be offensive to others. In my opinion, censorship can be beneficial when the content in books, movies, magazines, and music is untrue and offensive to a large group. For example, consider two books written about the same true event. The first book is well - written but may contain occasional offensive material, while the second book, due to censorship, may not present the complete story. Which one would you prefer to read? Personally, I would choose the book that provides the full account, even if it contains some offensive elements. Imagine being an author who has dedicated a significant amount of time and effort to write and publish a book. Naturally, one would hope to see their work on the library shelf. However, if the book contains content that may be offensive to others, it may not be allowed in the library. If the content is based on real - life events, why should children be exposed to a censored, potentially inaccurate version? I am not suggesting that young children should be given war books to read. When reading a book that an author has spent a great deal of time on, one is gaining insight into their perspective, which may differ from one's own, and this can be a positive experience. Even with offensive content, books, movies, magazines, and music can have value for some and not for others. I have visited libraries and found books that I was interested in but that I knew could be considered offensive by some. If the content of these media is untrue and offensive, then censorship is justifiable. However, censorship should be age - appropriate.
